title: Before 22 May 2020, will the Formula 1 Monaco Grand Prix auto race be postponed or canceled?
possible_answers: No, but public attendance will be restricted
No, and public attendance will not be restricted
preds: Given that the circuit build hasn’t commenced , it’s very unlikely that the race will go ahead.

They will be following a global trend of closures and cancellations, making it increasingly problematic for employers and venues not to cancel (the risks of enabling individuals to contract COVID-19 for non-essential tasks are growing, and could include civil suit liabilities). If the race is held, it will be without attendance.

On 17 March 2020, the Automobile Club de Monaco officially closed its doors due to government health directives [1]. This follows the cancellation of the first four races in the F1 circuit and currently, the lock-down is in effect indefinitely [2].  In order to build the Monaco Grand Prix track, it takes 7 weeks (this year is scheduled to be a historic Grand Prix race [3]), 250 paid workers, and 2,000 volunteers are working public spaces and moving equipment between Italy, France, and Monaco [4]. The current indefinite lockdown in Italy, which was just extended past 3 April [5] and the current 15-day lockdown in France [6] will make it difficult to move equipment to Monaco. Thus, both the equipment and manpower will be near impossible to utilize. Additionally, there is speculation that F1 is targeting the 1 June race in Azerbaijan as it's the first race of the season, and are in discussions with Monaco authorities on when the Monaco Grand prix can take place [7]. Another indication that the Monaco Grand Prix will be suspended or canceled is the unanimous vote by F1 teams to move the season's annual shut-down from August to the March-April timeframe and a vote is expected to be taken today to ratify the cancellation of this race [8]. I assess with a 100% probability that the Monaco Grand Prix will be canceled or Postponed before 22 May 2020. [1] https://www.pitpass.com/66752/Monaco-organizers-say-race-is-going-ahead
[2] https://www.essentiallysports.com/formula1-f1-news-monaco-gp-set-to-be-canceled/
[3] https://www.monacograndprixticket.com/grand-prix-historic/
[4] https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/features/2014/5/Monte-Carlos-miracle---making-Monaco-race-ready.html
[5] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/19/italys-death-rate-reaches-record-high-hospitals-in-lombardy-struggle.html
[6] https://www.france24.com/en/20200317-france-s-coronavirus-lockdown-what-you-can-and-can-t-do
[7] https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/formulaone/article-8112993/Formula-One-discuss-new-date-showpiece-Monaco-Grand-Prix-wake-coronavirus-pandemic.html
[8] https://www.express.co.uk/sport/f1-autosport/1257235/Spanish-Monaco-Brazilian-Grand-Prix-Cancelled-Coronavirus-F1-Shutdown-Move-2020-News
Most major European countries will be in profound crisis at this point.

There is almost a certain chance that the Grand Prix in Monaco will be postponed or canceled, due to the fact that the first four races of the season have been canceled and, as of right now, one team member from McLaren and one team member from Pirelli have been infected with the virus (IBT). The top priority of F1 teams is to ensure the safety of their team and due to the vast international effort that goes into a single Grand Prix, even restricting public attendance still does not prevent the possibility of spread from the people who travel from all over the world to work for the teams.  In almost all likelihood it will be postponed until the threat of the virus is lower or there are more effective treatments against it.
Revising due to Monaco being put in lockdown state. Facilities may not be built in time for May.

The "normal" length of a pandemic is 3 months.  Considering the situation in Europe started in early March, they should be seeing the end by the end of May.  Although with the measures taken to flatten the curve, 3 months might change to 6 months.
I am not putting a higher number as after such a long time of no economic activity, there will be a lot of pressure to get back to normal and start to pump more money into the economy

Reports are coming out that the Monaco Grand Prix will be canceled. Despite it being 2 months away, it improbable that it will occur.  [1] https://www.grandprix247.com/2020/03/16/report-monaco-grand-prix-to-be-officially-cancelled/
Hattip @fisherdbus for sealing the deal on my forecast.

With the move to delay the COVID-19 spread many public gatherings will be cancelled.   Grand-Prix racing requires a lot of planning, pls Monaco being on public roads will have potential priorities for emergency services.
With this much lead time I'd expect a system will be built to allow the race to happen.
Duh! Just getting in and back out would seem to be a logistic nightmare. Yes its 60 days away, but at some point it becomes impossible.
There will be a lot of travel restrictions all over the world, drivers and teams and audience are an extremely international crowd, that will seem too dangerous to gather
the show must go on. until may the crisis is over

For postponement/cancellation:
- Proximity to highly-hit countries such as France, Italy, Spain.
- Monaco is looking at cancelling/postponing a number of other conferences to autumn, including those with a lower attendee count than the Monaco Grand Prix. https://www.monaco-tribune.com/en/2020/03/prince-albert-ii-responds-to-covid-19-in-monaco/
- Dutch GP likely to be cancelled.
- Disaster of AU GP last-minute cancellation.
- Ticket sales are likely to be  highly affected even if it's safe to travel -> lower revenues means it's better to postpone. For going on:
- F1 is tentatively looking to start the season in end-May. If all goes well, Monaco Grand Prix might be the 1st of the season.
- Monaco currently only has 2 confirmed cases, one of the lowest in the region. As a small, wealthy country, it may be easier for authorities to keep infections in check.
- Prestige of Monaco Grand Prix.
- Tradition: held on last weekend of May. Up in the air:
- Spanish Grand Prix in talks on whether to cancel.
- Logistics need to start shipping in 1 month before. Cancellation should be determined by end-Apr -> will be looking at the effectiveness of lockdown measures in Europe.

Dutch GP has already been cancelled and that race takes place May 3 and Monaco only 19 days later. Hard to believe that it will go ahead on that date with no one even sure when the virus will peak. Monaco's two closest neighbours are Italy and France, which are two of the most affected countries. One would assume even if travel restrictions are lifted on other Euro countries, these two would be two of the last to have the restrictions lifted. There is already speculation that the race will move at least a week (Source: https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-51876784). Article also notes that Monaco GP pays no race fees, so there might be more appetite to drop it from from the program in favour of rescheduling for countries that do pay (massive) fees such as Bahrain and Vietnam. As for restricted / no spectators, the only major revenue stream races can draw on is ticket sales; Liberty (F1 parent company retains revenue from broadcast sales, corporate hospitality and on-track signage. Plus it's estimated 40% of attendees come from outside the host city, therefore being able to attract attendees is absolute necessity to help remain profitable and provide ancillary benefits to local businesses.  
(Source: https://www.forbes.com/sites/csylt/2017/03/13/formula-ones-5-7-billion-ticket-bonanza/#350359c72533) Seems like it will definitely move.

I think that it’s likely that the race will go ahead however there will be a number of restrictions to the public. My reasoning (at the moment).
- Given the measures that both Italy, France & Spain have taken in recent days to stop the spread of the virus, it is likely that over the next 14 - 28 days the rate of new infections will likely begin to stabilise and that by early May the rate will be consistently declining. 
- Monaco GP is the blue riband event on the GP calendar and the organisers will be keen to stage the event by whatever means possible.
- Monaco is somewhat unique in that there are few large spectator areas and is more appealing to a TV audience therefore the impact of restrictions to public entry will be less than any other GP
- Note, the circuit takes 6 weeks to build therefore events in the next two weeks will determine the outcome.

Thousands of people attend these races and that is the problem, any crowd over 100 is problematic for organizers.
A race can be held without spectators, but there are still hundreds of support staff who must be present during the event. If they can cancel March Madness which only requires a hundred staff, why would such a disruptive event be held? This is not a draw for the Casinos which should be empty anyway.

COVID-19 is blowing up in Europe and major races prior are being cancelled.  The best guess for a key date to restart season in end of May or start of June but rapidly escalating contagion will supersede that.
Cash is king, says Lewis Hamilton. But still Europe is epicentre say WHO.

Many Italians normally attend; they will still be badly affected. France is likely to catch up within about a month. F1 teams will not want a repeat of the Australian race being cancelled at the last moment. Also Monaco is a logistically difficult race for the teams, with little opportunity for separation; they are likely to want a resumption of the season at a larger venue.

There will be a realisation that transport to and from such events is an issue promising spread of the virus. In the case of outdoor events,  even if the event itself is low-risk (which is not certain about for this grand prix), holding such an event will lead to virus spread and that will lead to adverse publicity.

Teams have already discussed starting the season in Baku which would be after Monaco. It's one of the most prestigious races but they don't pay for the privilege of hosting so F1 management won't exactly be keen to see it held at all costs. The virus will also likely be around its peak (probably starting to decline) by then so I'd say it's very unlikely. First four races have already been postponed.
